displayed_text: Patient: Yes! I’ll take one. Doctor: You’ve got cancer, and I’m gonna treat ya. I’d like ya not to get the flu in the midst of therapy. Patient: Okay, then. Doctor: Because, then, it’s one thing I can cross off the list. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Umm. We could do it today, or we could do it in a couple weeks when you’re gonna switch the Patient: Whichever’s easiest to - Family Member: Why don’t we get it out of the way? Patient: Thanks, dear. Family Member: Well. Family Member: What are these? Patient: One less thing to worry about. (pause)

Patient: Oh, okay. Doctor: Because they’re not all the same. Patient: Right. Doctor: And so you always fuss about that. Because there’s other people giving high-dose vitamin C Patient: Yeah. Doctor: but you can’t guarantee the product. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Here I’m happy to say the product is definitely of high grade. Uh, but you’ve got to give it two days out of every week. Okay? So logistically that means as long as they are given twenty-four hours apart, you can just come up once, and the study pays for you to stay overnight at a hotel. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay? But that’s weekly. Patient: Okay, well I - Doctor: So like you’ll come up. You’ll get the one day where you get the chemo and the vitamin C. The next day 24 hours later you get vitamin C and you can go home.

Family Member: Yeah. You, you supply pill or do we have to use our insurance? Doctor: We supply the pills. Family Member: Okay. Healthcare Professional: Um, hum. Doctor: Yeah same with uh the study is to see if a second pill helps this pill work better so if you’re in the group that gets the second pill, we provide that too. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: So there’s nothing for you to do. Family Member: As long, as long as he get – as long as he’s on it? Doctor: Correct. Family Member: And they said he does this three months and then he comes back and get the pills? Healthcare Professional: Um, hum. Family Member: Right.

Doctor: Okay? Because again, you are sort of, your tongue’s sort of moving over, but your brain looks good. Doctor: Okay? Patient: All right. Doctor: But if it gets worse, it don’t make sense, I’d go back to the ER because I don’t know, because that’s what I would say, and it looks like your tongue’s a little bit more trouble getting over, huh, than the last time. Patient: Okay. I mean, these sometime it’s off and on. Sometimes I can you know- Doctor: Well, when you get tired it can do it. Patient: Yeah. So. Doctor: Okay? Patient: Okay. Doctor: Good. Patient: Thank you, doc. Doctor: Okay. Hang in there. Don’t forget your patch. Patient: Right.

Healthcare Professional: Okay. Doctor: Beautiful. Okay. Need any refills on anything? Patient: No. Doctor: Okay. So hang on and watch out for the uh yeah uh the diet and we’ll see you back in six weeks. Piece of cake. Patient: Six weeks? Doctor: Sure. Is that legit? Are you going to behave for six weeks? Patient: Oh, I always behave. Patient: Life is so boring. Doctor: Did I give you the nutrition book last time? Patient: No. Doctor: Oh, good. Parting gift. Patient: Parting gift?

Family Member: It’s not the biggest thing because people always ask you what’s your PSA. Doctor: Yeah, no, just say oh, I’m on a treatment where the PSA actually goes up and like, you know, we have a vaccine therapy that that happens but Xofigo for sure and we know that because actually one of the fellows who is now faculty wrote a paper on our collective experience when we first started doing it and Patient: Alright. I have something to run by you Doctor: Um hmm. Patient: with me going out of town and taking this. Would I be alright to travel? Doctor: Yeah. So, the good news is that we figured out that you will leave with a piece of paper after the radiation doctor gives you the injection because you will set off the TSA sensors. Patient: Okay Doctor: You will actually set off most sensors even though if you spilled it, which you don’t want to spill fifteen thousand on the floor but oops if you’re butterfingers and it goes ping all you have to do to stop the radiation spread is actually put a piece of paper over it and the way the rays, they don’t, it’s not like, it’s not what we call a beta emitter where it just goes crazy and everybody has to run, duck, and cover and take a little tick, tick, tick, you don’t have to do that. It covers it and it’s gone. But, the TSA sensors are so sensitive that it’s even below the threshold of what the radium is. So, they do give you a card kind of like when you get a bone scan, Patient: um humm. Doctor: you know, they’re like oh, I just had a bone scan, they’ll be a similar card, but just make sure you travel with that because you’ll set it off. You know, within like a week after you get it, it should be fine Patient: Okay Doctor: but that’s important to know. I’ll just give you my funny story because my patient when we first started, he was like number one or two and no one was travelling, right, he was like no, I’m not gonna travel. So, now I’m at home and it’s Sunday night and all the sudden my cellphone rings but it’s like nine p.m. and I’m like boy, that’s odd, who would be calling me. Not a number I recognize so I was like uh, do I pick it up, it’s probably a telemarketer, ah, okay. So, I picked it up and it was some guy he was is this Dr. H____? I’m like well, it depends, who wants to know.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: If there’s a lot there, so things look really dark, it looks like it’s taken up like crazy, then you’re a good candidate for that treatment. If it’s so-so, I don’t know what their line is, but they kind of look at it, and if it doesn’t look like the cancer is really taken off, I don’t think you’re a candidate. I would say that most people are in the first group that the cancer makes a lot of this uh so uh one of the things we’re doing here is uh looking at the scan part. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So we’ve been looking at the imaging part to see how useful this is as an imaging agent but it’s also useful because if we do it here, and you’re very positive, it might suggest yes we should pursue this. Patient: Okay. Is it something than can tell you how extensive the cancer? Doctor: Yes. So the second part of that, it’s a good question. Just to, and because it’s very sensitive, it’s possible you do the scan, and they, say, oh, B__, your set of these, so many things you see here, there’s a lot more. Because they can see uh, what we’re limited by right now is as I told you these lymph nodes are enlarged. That’s pretty much all the radiologist can say right now. So if you have a normal lymph node it could be totally full of cancer. They won’t call it. They only call the ones that are bigger than normal. Patient: I see. Doctor: That’s the criteria. Patient: I see. Doctor: So this PSMA scan picks up those normal things that are too small. So often patients will get upstaged in a way where you thought you had five things and told that you have ten. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So you’ve got to be prepared for that kind of news that there’s more there.

Patient: Yeah I… Doctor: I just - Give me a head’s up so I can talk to Dr. K____ and you know make that transition back. Patient: Uh huh. I see. Doctor: Just so he’s not shocked and you know he’s not panicking and calling me when you’re there in his office as to what happened. Patient: Ha-ha, yeah. Yeah. Family Member: So if his bone scan shows progression, are you gonna be in touch with him then? Doctor: I am. Family Member: Then he will start that? Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Yeah. Okay. And either way I think I will give him a head’s up especially – do you know when – do you have an appointment to see him? Patient: No, no, not right now we don’t.

Patient: Yes, yes. But we found that to be one of the cholesterol medications I was taking at the time. Doctor: Okay. Patient: And plus that in addition to I was getting a little cramp in my side. And so we stopped. Doctor: Well with age, so-called metabolic syndrome increases in many people. And so what that means is you know your sugar levels become higher and um your metabolism changes in such a way as a result of that. And this may also cause other downstream effects on the down the line. For example, it might slightly increase the risk of having a cardio-vascular disease or a heart attack, for example, or cerebral-vascular disease like a stroke. If the blood glucose level is not controlled over time. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: So all of the things that Metformin does is it changes your metabolism in such a way that the blood glucose level is lower and therefore it puts you at decreased risk of dying with those things that I mentioned. Patient: I’m sorry, it also mentioned that Metformin is a cancer fighter. Doctor: Right, there is some evidence which I would call modest. You know in other words it’s not absolutely conclusive, but it’s not you know terribly weak either um that , at prostate cancer specifically, and other cancers in general, there might be a direct anti tumor effect Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: Now uhm I am somewhat convinced by the data. Uhm the perfect way to prove that, and this may never happen, is to actually design a trial. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Where you take people that already have a diagnosis of prostate cancer – Patient: Uh hum.

Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: and will continue to. I know G___ asked you a lot about that. Patient: Yeah. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: He wrote three pads and… So do you want to see Dr. F__? Family Member: If it’s okay with you, I mean… Doctor: Yeah it’s okay with me. Family Member: He’s a good guy. Doctor: Uh huh, Yeah I think he’s excellent. I haven’t talked to him in a long time, but he and I are close. We used to talk all the time. Family Member: Okay. Gives you a good reason for you to get back together (Laughs) Doctor: M____. Family Member: He’s at M___ because I worked there.

Family Member: So in other words this third option, the chemo and the hormones—so when the chemo ends he’ll be getting radiation while he continues to get the hormone therapy. Doctor: Yeah and we give the chemo and the super hormones for three months. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: And then give you about time to recover about six to eight weeks later. Then we do the radiation, uh which puts you at about sort of eight months, you know out, so then you’d have another; it’s a total of two years of hormones. Patient: Okay and then how frequently will my PSA be tested while I’m doing the chemo? Doctor: Every month. Patient: Okay, so you’ll know whether the castration is working or not with the hormone Family Member: After the three months of the chemo and hormone pills, how does the hormone deprivation continue? Is that – it starts now? Okay. Doctor: About every three months. Family Member: I’m sorry if you said this, but how long does the radiation go? Doctor: The radiation takes two months, coming to the hospital five days a week. I forget where you live. Patient: C___

Patient: Bonus with what I had in front of me. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: And then realized we gotta go. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: You know? We went to a restaurant and was like, no, we gotta go. Doctor: Um hum. Patient: I’ve gotta box this up. You know? As it was I was a little bit late Family Member: You ate half of it. Doctor: No. That’s okay. You should never rush to come here. You know that. You just come when you can safely. I’m not going anywhere. So next time just finish whatever you’ve gotta finish. Patient: Well, we, we, we, started now much late. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: But then we ran into,there’s a ballgame.

Patient: Sure. Sure. Doctor: You could go on before you uh, I think their trial is a, so it’s called a phase one trial. So what does that mean? So phase one traditionally was uh a dose-finding trial. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So it determines how toxic things were. Patient: Um hum. Um hum. Doctor: So with drugs what will often happen is a patient on a phase one where you came at an early stage you’d get a very low dose, probably too low to have toxicity but too low to be effective. And when you get to the high dose, it might be plenty to be effective but toxic, so you’d always sort of be Goldilocks at the end. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: For this, I’ve got a, I think for this, the trial, they were able to use the experience with Germany to say you probably could start about here. You don’t have to start way down here. And I don’t think it’s the same exactly like a regular drug phase one. So I think they’re kind of already in a in a sort of Goldilocks spot. Patient: Okay. Okay. Doctor: So that’s the only difference between you know in Germany everybody gets, they individualize it based on what they looked at is how much of the scan is your cancer taking off. They try, they, they describe what they said that if you took up that much material, you need to get this much. Patient: Yes. Doctor: So they give, they dose it based on how much of an exposure. Patient: Um hum.

Patient: But then we ran into,there’s a ballgame. Doctor: I heard there was something going on seventy-five today too. Patient: Middle of that, yes. Doctor: There was some massive drama on seventy-five. Family Member: Oh. Hope we missed it. Patient: No. We ran into it. Doctor: But it was south of here. Something happened south. Patient: Yeah. We ran into it. Doctor: I don’t know what happened. Somebody tried, I don’t know if it was a suicide case or something but they blocked all the lanes or something was going on. Family Member: Yeah. I heard about that earlier today. Doctor: Something was going on so everybody was all discombobulated today. Family Member: It was north and south going into Ohio. Doctor: Yeah. That’s what it was. That was what it was. A little scary.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.3 times: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::3 times

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.strongly disagree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.::: strongly disagree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.strongly agree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::strongly agree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.agree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::agree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.strongly agree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::strongly agree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.agree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::agree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.strongly agree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::strongly agree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.strongly agree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::strongly agree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.neutral: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::neutral

Which of the following best describe you.Retired: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Retired

What is the highest grade or level of s.Some college: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::Some college

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.White: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::White

Please feel free to leave any comments a.text_box: interesting interactions with Doctors. Tho i think most act in a profesional manner and do the best they can for all

displayed_text: Family Member: Right. Right. Doctor: But we haven’t had a scan since April of last year. So we might as well get one this year. Family Member: Yes. Doctor: See how things are. You know? See how the lymph nodes and bone stuff is doing just to make sure we don’t have to do anything exciting. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: You okay with that? So that’s the CAT scan again, there’s the chest, the bone in the pelvis, and then the bone scan, which is basically stuff like that. Just to make sure. Patient: Hum. Hum. Doctor: And we’ll compare it to all the ones before. Family Member: Oh, okay. Doctor: This is not a huge jump. Family Member: Oh. Doctor: Nothing that I’m going to freak out about. But we want to be prepared in case it’s starting to wake up. Patient: Hum.
